<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Here I will show you how to use generalised linear models (GLM) with mortality claims data. We will fit a poisson GLM to model count data using the h2o package. This post will cover:</p>
<ul>
<li>Preparing data</li>
<li>Basic h2o functions</li>
<li>Use of offsets</li>
<li>Fitting a basic GLM</li>
<li>Extracting a rating plan from the model</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This article will be split into two parts - part 1 will cover the above and part 2 will cover cross validation and 'tuning' a GLM using h2o's grid search functionality. Finally, in a later post we will look at how to build simple pricing apps using the models we develop.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Background">Background<a class="anchor-link" href="#Background">¶</a></h2><p>Imagine a portfolio of lives with lump sum death benefit cover - we want to be able to model how many claims will arise from this portfolio. The number of claims will obviously vary depending on how long each life has insurance cover in place.</p>
<p>GLMs are widely used by actuaries to set rating plans that are used to price insurance products - particularly in general insurance (personal lines etc). One of the benefits of using GLMs is that it's usually easy to extract an interpretable, often simple, rating plan from the model (this is discussed in more detail later). A GLM also allows us to update an existing rating plan rather than set an entirely new one. An existing rating plan may have been set, for example, using standard tables.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Data">Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Data">¶</a></h2><p>I'll use a simulated dataset created <a href="https://josho88.github.io/Simulating%20Data.html">in a previous post</a>. This dataset contains 1.5m records. Each record represents an individual and the columns contain their age, gender, occupation, location, salary details, exposure (how long, in years, the individual was insured) and whether or not a claim was made under their policy. To create this dataset you can follow the previous <a href="https://josho88.github.io/Simulating%20Data.html">tutorial</a> or alternatively any similar dataset should be fine.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Read in the data</span>
dt <span class="o">=</span> read.csv<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'SimData.csv'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="kp">head</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">id</th><th scope="col">Age</th><th scope="col">Male</th><th scope="col">Occupation</th><th scope="col">Salary</th><th scope="col">Location</th><th scope="col">Exposure</th><th scope="col">Claim</th><th scope="col">Age_Last</th><th scope="col">Salary_Band</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>1       </td><td>37.19762</td><td>1       </td><td>3       </td><td>45585.80</td><td>4       </td><td>1.260529</td><td>0       </td><td>37      </td><td>4       </td></tr>
<tr><td>2       </td><td>38.84911</td><td>1       </td><td>1       </td><td>55209.32</td><td>3       </td><td>1.496348</td><td>0       </td><td>38      </td><td>4       </td></tr>
<tr><td>3       </td><td>47.79354</td><td>0       </td><td>1       </td><td>40840.58</td><td>3       </td><td>0.607670</td><td>0       </td><td>47      </td><td>3       </td></tr>
<tr><td>4       </td><td>40.35254</td><td>1       </td><td>1       </td><td>32138.86</td><td>3       </td><td>2.968844</td><td>0       </td><td>40      </td><td>2       </td></tr>
<tr><td>5       </td><td>40.64644</td><td>1       </td><td>3       </td><td>60397.61</td><td>1       </td><td>1.021152</td><td>0       </td><td>40      </td><td>4       </td></tr>
<tr><td>6       </td><td>48.57532</td><td>1       </td><td>1       </td><td>25626.29</td><td>1       </td><td>2.915284</td><td>0       </td><td>48      </td><td>2       </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>For ideas on exploring this dataset using summary statistics and visualisations, refer to <a href="https://josho88.github.io/Simulating%20Data.html">this post</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Import-Libraries">Import Libraries<a class="anchor-link" href="#Import-Libraries">¶</a></h2><p>The h2o package will be used extensively. Dplyr will also be needed. Import these libraries using the following commands:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o<span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>dplyr<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In order to use h2o functions, we need to initialise an h2o cluster. Use the <code>h2o.init()</code> function. For example:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>h2o.init<span class="p">(</span>nthreads <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">-1</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># convert data to h2o frame</span>
h2o_data <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Existing-Plan">Existing Plan<a class="anchor-link" href="#Existing-Plan">¶</a></h2><p>Often, a rating plan is already in place and rather than start from scratch we may just want to add to (or update) this existing model. For example, we might already have a best estimate of claim rates for the general population which aren't being updated as part of this exercise, but we want to use the GLM to refine these rates. In this example I'll define the existing estimate of claim rates to be:</p>
<ul>
<li>Individuals under 40 will be assumed, on average, to claim at a rate of $\frac{1}{1000}$</li>
<li>Individuals aged 40-49 have a claim rate of $\frac{1.5}{1000}$</li>
<li>Ages 50 + have a claim rate of $\frac{2}{1000}$</li>
</ul>
<p>These baseline rates vary by age but not gender, occupation and so on. The GLM can be used to refine these initial estimates so that the final predicted claim count allows for our other predictor variables.</p>
<p>Next, we need to add these base rates to each record. Of course, each individual won't necessarily have been the same age for the entire period they were covered under a policy! However, for simplicity here I'm going to assume that age is the average age over the exposure period and just set our best estimate of mortality based on this average age. In reality, a more realistic expectation of mortality may be used - based on age varying over the exposure period.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span>ages <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">as.vector</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Age_Last<span class="p">)</span>
Base_Rate <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">ifelse</span><span class="p">(</span>ages <span class="o">%in%</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="m">39</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="m">0.001</span><span class="p">,</span>
            <span class="kp">ifelse</span><span class="p">(</span>ages <span class="o">%in%</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">40</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="m">49</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="m">0.0015</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="m">0.002</span><span class="p">))</span>
h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Base_Rate <span class="o">=</span> h2o.asnumeric<span class="p">(</span>as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>Base_Rate<span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To allow for these base rates in the GLM model an offset column needs to be added.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Adding-an-Offset-Column">Adding an Offset Column<a class="anchor-link" href="#Adding-an-Offset-Column">¶</a></h2><p>An offset is a covariate in the model with a coefficient constrained to be one (rather than being estimated). In this model, we need to add two offsets - one to allow for exposure and one to allow for the fact that we do not wish to update our base rates as part of this process.</p>
<h3 id="Why-use-an-offset-to-allow-for-exposure?">Why use an offset to allow for exposure?<a class="anchor-link" href="#Why-use-an-offset-to-allow-for-exposure?">¶</a></h3><p>Mathematically, the poisson model takes the form:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>However, since our response variable is actually claims per unit of exposure, we are modelling a rate. Which takes the form:</p>
<p>$$log(\frac{\mu}{exposure}) = \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>This is equivalent to:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) - log(exposure) = \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>Finally, $log(exposure)$ enters the right hand side of the equation as an offset with coefficient constrained to one, giving:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(exposure) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<h3 id="Why-use-an-offset-for-base-rates?">Why use an offset for base rates?<a class="anchor-link" href="#Why-use-an-offset-for-base-rates?">¶</a></h3><p>As mentioned earlier, our base rates are derived outside of this model and are not being updated here. However, these base rates will still form part of the overall rating plan and so the GLM model needs to be made aware of them. The other loadings will be optimised once our base rates have been applied. Therefore, base_rate enters the RHS of the equation as follows:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(exposure) + log(base\_rate) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>And since $log(a) + log(b) = log(ab)$ this can be simplified as:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(exposure\times base\_rate) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>Which is equivalent to:</p>
<p>$$log(\mu) = log(\mathbb{E}[deaths]) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n$$</p>
<p>Therefore, the final offset to be included in the model is $log(\mathbb{E}[deaths])$</p>
<p>So, next we need to calculate $\mathbb{E}[deaths]$ for each record. This will be our base rate multiplied by the exposure period. Then the data can be split into train, test and holdout sets and the offset columns are added.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Calculate the 'expected deaths' for each record</span>
h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Expected_Deaths <span class="o">=</span> h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Exposure <span class="o">*</span> h2o_data<span class="o">$</span>Base_Rate
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># First, set Occupation and Location variables as nominal factor variables</span>
<span class="c1"># (salary band isn't strictly nominal but we'll treat it as such here)</span>
h2o_data<span class="p">[</span><span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Occupation'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Location'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Salary_Band'</span><span class="p">)]</span> <span class="o">=</span>
    h2o.asfactor<span class="p">(</span>h2o_data<span class="p">[</span><span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Occupation'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Location'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Salary_Band'</span><span class="p">)])</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Separate into a train, test and holdout set</span>
<span class="c1"># 60% in training and 20% in test & holdout respectively</span>
split <span class="o">=</span> h2o.splitFrame<span class="p">(</span>h2o_data<span class="p">,</span> ratios <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">0.6</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">0.2</span><span class="p">),</span> seed <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">123</span><span class="p">)</span>
train <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">split</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">]]</span>
test <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">split</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="m">2</span><span class="p">]]</span>
holdout <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">split</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="m">3</span><span class="p">]]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Since the dataset is large and the claim event is rare I am going to reduce the datasets using aggregation. In the aggregated datasets each row will represent a feature set and the claims and exposure columns will be the sum of all claims/exposure in that given set. In practice, for a poisson GLM it doesn't make a difference to the model whether we use aggregated or full individual data.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Define a helper function to aggregate the train, test and holdout sets</span>

agg <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kr">function</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o_frame<span class="p">){</span>
  dat <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">as.data.frame</span><span class="p">(</span>h2o_frame<span class="p">)</span>
  agg_data <span class="o">=</span> aggregate<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="p">[</span><span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Exposure'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s">'Claim'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s">'Expected_Deaths'</span><span class="p">)],</span>
                       by <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">list</span><span class="p">(</span>Age <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="o">$</span>Age_Last<span class="p">,</span>
                                 Male <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="o">$</span>Male<span class="p">,</span>
                                 Occupation <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="o">$</span>Occupation<span class="p">,</span>
                                 Location <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="o">$</span>Location<span class="p">,</span>
                                 Salary_Band <span class="o">=</span> dat<span class="o">$</span>Salary_Band<span class="p">),</span>
                       FUN <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">sum</span><span class="p">)</span>
  agg_data
<span class="p">}</span>

<span class="c1"># create aggregated versions of datasets</span>
train_aggregated <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>agg<span class="p">(</span>train<span class="p">))</span>
test_aggregated <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>agg<span class="p">(</span>test<span class="p">))</span>
holdout_aggregated <span class="o">=</span> as.h2o<span class="p">(</span>agg<span class="p">(</span>holdout<span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Aggregated data now looks like:</span>
<span class="kp">head</span><span class="p">(</span>train_aggregated<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">Age</th><th scope="col">Male</th><th scope="col">Occupation</th><th scope="col">Location</th><th scope="col">Salary_Band</th><th scope="col">Exposure</th><th scope="col">Claim</th><th scope="col">Expected_Deaths</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>18         </td><td>0          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td> 2.085132  </td><td>0          </td><td>0.002085132</td></tr>
<tr><td>21         </td><td>0          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td> 2.631169  </td><td>0          </td><td>0.002631169</td></tr>
<tr><td>22         </td><td>0          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td> 5.514519  </td><td>0          </td><td>0.005514519</td></tr>
<tr><td>23         </td><td>0          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>15.261279  </td><td>0          </td><td>0.015261279</td></tr>
<tr><td>24         </td><td>0          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>14.850105  </td><td>0          </td><td>0.014850105</td></tr>
<tr><td>25         </td><td>0          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>1          </td><td>35.883652  </td><td>0          </td><td>0.035883652</td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [14]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Now, add the offsets to train, test and holdout sets</span>
train_aggregated<span class="o">$</span>Offset <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">log</span><span class="p">(</span>train_aggregated<span class="o">$</span>Expected_Deaths<span class="p">)</span>
test_aggregated<span class="o">$</span>Offset <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">log</span><span class="p">(</span>test_aggregated<span class="o">$</span>Expected_Deaths<span class="p">)</span>
holdout_aggregated<span class="o">$</span>Offset <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">log</span><span class="p">(</span>holdout_aggregated<span class="o">$</span>Expected_Deaths<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [15]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Finally, let's just make sure we set all our factor variables properly in the</span>
<span class="c1"># aggregated data sets</span>

factorVars <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Salary_Band'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Occupation'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Location'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Male'</span><span class="p">)</span>
train_aggregated<span class="p">[</span>factorVars<span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> h2o.asfactor<span class="p">(</span>train_aggregated<span class="p">[</span>factorVars<span class="p">])</span>
test_aggregated<span class="p">[</span>factorVars<span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> h2o.asfactor<span class="p">(</span>test_aggregated<span class="p">[</span>factorVars<span class="p">])</span>
holdout_aggregated<span class="p">[</span>factorVars<span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> h2o.asfactor<span class="p">(</span>holdout_aggregated<span class="p">[</span>factorVars<span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Fitting-the-GLM">Fitting the GLM<a class="anchor-link" href="#Fitting-the-GLM">¶</a></h2><p>The GLM will be built using the h2o package. First, define the set of predictors we will use and the name of the column to be used as an offset. Then, the model is fit using <code>h2o.glm()</code>. Be careful to define the 'family' as poisson. Setting lambda = 0 means that this baseline model will not apply any regularisation. To check the performance against holdout data use <code>h2o.performance()</code>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Fit a basic GLM - with NO regularisation (discussed in part 2)</span>
<span class="c1"># Need to set alpha = 0 and lambda = 0 as h2o uses regularisation by default.</span>
<span class="c1"># Setting these to 0 overrides this.</span>

predictors <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">'Salary_Band'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Occupation'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Location'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s">'Male'</span><span class="p">)</span>
response <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Claim'</span>
offset <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Offset'</span>

mod1 <span class="o">=</span> h2o.glm<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> predictors<span class="p">,</span>
               y <span class="o">=</span> response<span class="p">,</span>
               training_frame <span class="o">=</span> train_aggregated<span class="p">,</span>
               validation_frame <span class="o">=</span> test_aggregated<span class="p">,</span>
               family <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'poisson'</span><span class="p">,</span>
               offset_column <span class="o">=</span> offset<span class="p">,</span>
               alpha <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span>lambda <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span>
               intercept <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">,</span>
               compute_p_values <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">TRUE</span><span class="p">,</span>
               seed <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">123</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Extracting-the-Ratings">Extracting the Ratings<a class="anchor-link" href="#Extracting-the-Ratings">¶</a></h2><p>To set a rating plan we need to extract the coefficient estimates from the model and convert these to ratings. Since the poisson GLM uses a log link function we can get to the final ratings by taking exponentials of both sides of the GLM equation. For example, to derive $\mu$ our equation becomes:</p>
<p>$$\mu = \exp(log(\mathbb{E}[deaths]) + \alpha + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + ... + \beta_n x_n) $$</p>
<p>Which is equivalent to:</p>
<p>$$\mu = \mathbb{E}[deaths] \times \exp(\alpha) \times \exp(\beta_1 x_1) \times \exp(\beta_2 x_2) \times ... \times \exp(\beta_n x_n)$$</p>
<p>We can see that the final rating plan will therefore be multiplicative.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Extracting the ratings</span>
mod1_ratings <span class="o">=</span> mod1<span class="o">@</span>model<span class="o">$</span>coefficients_table
mod1_ratings<span class="o">$</span>rating <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">exp</span><span class="p">(</span>mod1_ratings<span class="o">$</span>coefficients<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># View the table of coefficients</span>
<span class="c1"># (some rounding has been applied using dplyr mutate function)</span>
mod1_ratings <span class="o">%>%</span> 
    mutate_if<span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">is.numeric</span><span class="p">,</span> funs<span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">.</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="m">3</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">names</th><th scope="col">coefficients</th><th scope="col">std_error</th><th scope="col">z_value</th><th scope="col">p_value</th><th scope="col">standardized_coefficients</th><th scope="col">rating</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>Intercept    </td><td> 0.230       </td><td>0.084        </td><td> 2.748       </td><td>0.006        </td><td> 0.230       </td><td>1.259        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Salary_Band.2</td><td>-0.010       </td><td>0.064        </td><td>-0.163       </td><td>0.871        </td><td>-0.010       </td><td>0.990        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Salary_Band.3</td><td> 0.035       </td><td>0.066        </td><td> 0.526       </td><td>0.599        </td><td> 0.035       </td><td>1.035        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Salary_Band.4</td><td>-0.015       </td><td>0.064        </td><td>-0.229       </td><td>0.819        </td><td>-0.015       </td><td>0.986        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Salary_Band.5</td><td>-0.118       </td><td>0.095        </td><td>-1.247       </td><td>0.213        </td><td>-0.118       </td><td>0.889        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Location.2   </td><td> 0.078       </td><td>0.087        </td><td> 0.899       </td><td>0.369        </td><td> 0.078       </td><td>1.082        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Location.3   </td><td> 0.177       </td><td>0.078        </td><td> 2.281       </td><td>0.023        </td><td> 0.177       </td><td>1.194        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Location.4   </td><td> 0.167       </td><td>0.086        </td><td> 1.945       </td><td>0.052        </td><td> 0.167       </td><td>1.182        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Occupation.2 </td><td>-0.152       </td><td>0.060        </td><td>-2.529       </td><td>0.011        </td><td>-0.152       </td><td>0.859        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Occupation.3 </td><td>-0.141       </td><td>0.055        </td><td>-2.565       </td><td>0.010        </td><td>-0.141       </td><td>0.869        </td></tr>
<tr><td>Male.1       </td><td>-0.084       </td><td>0.044        </td><td>-1.913       </td><td>0.056        </td><td>-0.084       </td><td>0.919        </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The final rating plan takes the form:</p>
<p>Base rate $\times$ exposure $\times$ intercept $\times$ salary rating $\times$ location rating $\times$ occupation rating $\times$ gender rating</p>
<p>This simple plan can then be used to estimate the claim rate for an individual or a group of lives with similar features. We can work through the first row in the holdout dataset to see how the model could be used in practice.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="kp">head</span><span class="p">(</span>holdout<span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">id</th><th scope="col">Age</th><th scope="col">Male</th><th scope="col">Occupation</th><th scope="col">Salary</th><th scope="col">Location</th><th scope="col">Exposure</th><th scope="col">Claim</th><th scope="col">Age_Last</th><th scope="col">Salary_Band</th><th scope="col">Base_Rate</th><th scope="col">Expected_Deaths</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>9          </td><td>36.56574   </td><td>1          </td><td>2          </td><td>57991.43   </td><td>4          </td><td>1.124758   </td><td>0          </td><td>36         </td><td>4          </td><td>0.001      </td><td>0.001124758</td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The ratings for a male, occupation class 2, living in location category 4 in salary band 4 are as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>Gender - 0.919</li>
<li>Occupation - 0.859</li>
<li>Location - 1.182</li>
<li>Salary band - 0.986</li>
</ul>
<p>So the claim rate would be:</p>
<p>$$ 0.001 \times 1.124758 \times 0.919 \times 0.859 \times 1.182 \times  0.986 = 0.00103$$</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Conclusion">Conclusion<a class="anchor-link" href="#Conclusion">¶</a></h2><p>You should now be able to fit a basic GLM using the h2o package and use the resulting model to set an insurance rating plan. In part 2 I will cover:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cross validating the model</li>
<li>Automatically tuning the model using h2o's grid search functionality - this allows us to automatically try hundreds (even thousands) of different GLM's, with different input parameters, in order to select the best model for this dataset</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>

        "    jax: ['input/TeX','input/MathML','output/HTML-CSS']," +

        "        processEscapes: true," +
        "        preview: 'TeX'," +
        "    }, " +
        "    'HTML-CSS': { " +
        " linebreaks: { automatic: true, width: '95% container' }, " +
        "        styles: { '.MathJax_Display, .MathJax .mo, .MathJax .mi, .MathJax .mn': {color: 'black ! important'} }" +
        "    } " +
        "}); ";
    (document.body || document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0]).appendChild(mathjaxscript);
}

entry.title: Simulating a Mortality Dataset in R
entry.summary: In this post I'll show you how to simulate a large dataset of mortality claims. Sometimes it's useful to use simulated data. For example, if you wanted to experiment with new modelling techniques but were unable to find a useful dataset, it may be easiest just to create your own. Alternatively, you may simply wish to supplement existing data with simulated data. If you have some assumptions about the variables you want to create, it's possible to create entire datasets from scratch.

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In this post I'll show you how to simulate a large dataset of mortality claims. Sometimes it's useful to use simulated data. For example, if you wanted to experiment with new modelling techniques but were unable to find a useful dataset, it may be easiest just to create your own. Alternatively, you may simply wish to supplement existing data with simulated data. If you have some assumptions about the variables you want to create, it's possible to create entire datasets from scratch.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Example">Example<a class="anchor-link" href="#Example">¶</a></h2><p>Imagine that you wanted to experiment with fitting different predictive models to life insurance claims data (perhaps to practice your coding skills or to explore an idea) but didn't have all the data required. Rather than spend time searching for or collecting large volumes of data appropriate for your specific problem, you could simply (and quickly) create a simulated dataset.</p>
<p>I will show you how to create a dataset representing a portfolio of lives with lump sum life insurance cover, but the following techniques can be used to create all sorts of data. We will end up with a large dataset where each row will represent one life and the columns will contain information about that persons age, salary, occupation, gender, location and, finally, whether or not that person died during a specific period.</p>
<p>In order to do this we will need to come up with some assumptions about the variables we wish to create. The assumptions I will make will be very simple and are listed below.</p>
<div class="alert alert-block alert-info"> Age: Normally distributed with mean age = 40 and variance = 25
<br/>
Gender: 40% of the sample will be Male, 60% female
<br/>
Occupation: 3 categories representing different occupations. 50% of the lives will be in category 1, 20% in category 2 and 30% in category 3
<br/>
Location: 4 categories representing different areas of residence. 10% will be in category 1, 20% in category 2, 50% in category 3 and 20% in category 4
<br/>
Salary: Gamma distributed. I will assume that salary varies by age and occupation
<br/>
Exposure: This variable represents the length of time (in years) that each person was covered for. This will come from a uniform(0,3) distribution (i.e the maximum cover period is 3 years)
<br/>
Claim: I will assume that the probability of death is a formula linked to age and occupation. The base level of mortality will be $\frac{Age}{20000}$. Mortality increases by 20% for those in occupation category 1 and by 15% for those living in locations 3 or 4</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Creating-the-data-in-R">Creating the data in R<a class="anchor-link" href="#Creating-the-data-in-R">¶</a></h2><h3 id="Setting-Assumptions">Setting Assumptions<a class="anchor-link" href="#Setting-Assumptions">¶</a></h3><p>I'll assume you have R Studio installed and some experience with basic R programming. If you have not used R before, I recommend visiting <a href="https://www.datacamp.com">https://www.datacamp.com</a> and taking the free intro to R course. We will be using the simstudy package. If you have not yet installed this package, run <code>install.packages('simstudy')</code> to do so.</p>
<p>Simstudy first requires us to generate a table containing our assumptions. Each row in this table will contain information relating to one of our variables. We will need to specify a name for each variable, the distribution we wish to simulate from and formula for the mean of each variable (and in some cases, variance). To create the assumptions data, use the <code>defData()</code> function.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>First, load the necessary libraries.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>simstudy<span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kn">library</span><span class="p">(</span>ggplot2<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># initialise our assumptions table and add the Age variable</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Age'</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'normal'</span><span class="p">,</span> formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">40</span><span class="p">,</span> variance <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">25</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># the assumptions table has now been created and can be viewed</span>
def
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">varname</th><th scope="col">formula</th><th scope="col">variance</th><th scope="col">dist</th><th scope="col">link</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>Age     </td><td>40      </td><td>25      </td><td>normal  </td><td>identity</td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>To add to this table, use the <code>defData()</code> function again, but this time specifying the name of the table we've just created using the <code>dtDefs</code> argument. For example, add the gender, occupation, location and exposure variables as follows:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># add a binary variable to indicate gender - 40% of lives will be Male </span>
<span class="c1"># and will be represented by as 1's</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>dtDefs <span class="o">=</span> def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Gender"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"binary"</span><span class="p">,</span> formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0.4</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># add a categorical variable to define occupation type.</span>
<span class="c1"># There will be three classes.</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>dtDefs <span class="o">=</span> def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Occupation"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"categorical"</span><span class="p">,</span>formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"0.5;0.2;0.3"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># add the location variable to the data table</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>dtDefs <span class="o">=</span> def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Location"</span><span class="p">,</span>dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"categorical"</span><span class="p">,</span>formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"0.1;0.2;0.5;0.2"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># add a variable to indicate 'exposure years'</span>
<span class="c1"># (in other words, the length of time an individual was insured)</span>
def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>def<span class="p">,</span> varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">'Exposure'</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"uniform"</span><span class="p">,</span> formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"0;3"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># the assumptions table now looks like:</span>
def
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">varname</th><th scope="col">formula</th><th scope="col">variance</th><th scope="col">dist</th><th scope="col">link</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>Age            </td><td>40             </td><td>25             </td><td>normal         </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Gender         </td><td>0.4            </td><td> 0             </td><td>binary         </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Occupation     </td><td>0.5;0.2;0.3    </td><td> 0             </td><td>categorical    </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Location       </td><td>0.1;0.2;0.5;0.2</td><td> 0             </td><td>categorical    </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
<tr><td>Exposure       </td><td>0;3            </td><td> 0             </td><td>uniform        </td><td>identity       </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Since salary and claim depend on other variables, the 'formula' argument for these variables will be a bit more complicated. I have used the <code>paste()</code> function to specify the formulas to be passed into <code>defData()</code>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># add a salary variable - the mean of which will increase </span>
<span class="c1"># with age and will vary by occupation class.</span>
<span class="c1"># Use a gamma distribution</span>

salary_formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">paste</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"ifelse(Occupation == 1, Age * 800, </span>
<span class="s">                        ifelse(Occupation == 2, Age * 1200, Age * 1350))"</span><span class="p">)</span>

def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>def<span class="p">,</span>varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Salary"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"gamma"</span><span class="p">,</span>
              formula <span class="o">=</span> salary_formula<span class="p">,</span>variance <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">0.2</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Now, add the binary claim indicator</span>
<span class="c1"># (the probability of death varies as specified earlier)</span>
claim_formula <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">paste</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"(Age * 1/20000)"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                      <span class="s">" * ifelse(Occupation == 1,1.2,1)"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                      <span class="s">" * ifelse(Location %in% c(3,4), 1.15,1)"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                      sep <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">""</span><span class="p">)</span>

def <span class="o">=</span> defData<span class="p">(</span>def<span class="p">,</span> varname <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"Claim"</span><span class="p">,</span> dist <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s">"binary"</span><span class="p">,</span>formula <span class="o">=</span> claim_formula<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># the final assumptions table now looks like:</span>
def
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">varname</th><th scope="col">formula</th><th scope="col">variance</th><th scope="col">dist</th><th scope="col">link</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>Age                                                                                                          </td><td>40                                                                                                           </td><td>25.0                                                                                                         </td><td>normal                                                                                                       </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Gender                                                                                                       </td><td>0.4                                                                                                          </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>binary                                                                                                       </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Occupation                                                                                                   </td><td>0.5;0.2;0.3                                                                                                  </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>categorical                                                                                                  </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Location                                                                                                     </td><td>0.1;0.2;0.5;0.2                                                                                              </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>categorical                                                                                                  </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Exposure                                                                                                     </td><td>0;3                                                                                                          </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>uniform                                                                                                      </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Salary                                                                                                       </td><td>ifelse(Occupation == 1, Age * 800, 
                        ifelse(Occupation == 2, Age * 1200, Age * 1350))</td><td> 0.2                                                                                                         </td><td>gamma                                                                                                        </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
<tr><td>Claim                                                                                                        </td><td>(Age * 1/20000) * ifelse(Occupation == 1,1.2,1) * ifelse(Location %in% c(3,4), 1.15,1)                       </td><td> 0.0                                                                                                         </td><td>binary                                                                                                       </td><td>identity                                                                                                     </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Generating-the-Data">Generating the Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Generating-the-Data">¶</a></h3><p>Now, actually generating the data is easy. Do this using the <code>genData()</code> function. The first argument, n, is how many records you want to simulate. Then just pass in the name of the assumptions table. I will simulate 1.5m records.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># simulate 1.5m records</span>
dt <span class="o">=</span> genData<span class="p">(</span>n <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">1500000</span><span class="p">,</span>def<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># view the first few rows</span>
<span class="kp">head</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table class="table-striped table table-hover">
<thead><tr><th scope="col">id</th><th scope="col">Age</th><th scope="col">Gender</th><th scope="col">Occupation</th><th scope="col">Location</th><th scope="col">Exposure</th><th scope="col">Salary</th><th scope="col">Claim</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
<tr><td>1        </td><td>42.08506 </td><td>1        </td><td>3        </td><td>1        </td><td>2.7495713</td><td>38489.57 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>2        </td><td>45.20828 </td><td>0        </td><td>2        </td><td>2        </td><td>1.2410225</td><td>35048.71 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>3        </td><td>31.44311 </td><td>0        </td><td>1        </td><td>3        </td><td>0.6282520</td><td>20921.03 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>4        </td><td>49.38805 </td><td>1        </td><td>2        </td><td>4        </td><td>0.2876624</td><td>94668.40 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>5        </td><td>33.44234 </td><td>1        </td><td>1        </td><td>4        </td><td>2.3408016</td><td>15132.47 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
<tr><td>6        </td><td>42.73697 </td><td>1        </td><td>2        </td><td>2        </td><td>0.5534407</td><td>60448.24 </td><td>0        </td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Exploring-the-Simulated-Data">Exploring the Simulated Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Exploring-the-Simulated-Data">¶</a></h3><p>Now, we can summarise and visualise the dataset that has been created to check that everything is as expected. The <code>summary()</code> and <code>table()</code> functions are very useful and the ggplot2 library is particularly good for creating visualisations. Use the <code>ggplot()</code> function to create density plots, bar charts and scatter plots to check that distributions have been created according to our specified assumptions and to check the relationships between variables. If you have not installed ggplot2, execute <code>install.packages('ggplot2')</code></p>
<p>First, use <code>summary()</code> to see statistics for the entire dataset. Then use <code>table()</code> and <code>prop.table()</code> to see how claims vary by occupation and/or location.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Summary stats</span>
<span class="kp">summary</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="kp">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Claim rate by occupation"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># prop table can be used to convert the tables above to percentages</span>
<span class="kp">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Occupation"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="kp">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">prop.table</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">table</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Occupation<span class="p">,</span> dt<span class="o">$</span>Claim<span class="p">),</span> margin<span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">1</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="m">5</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea ">
<pre>       id               Age            Gender         Occupation   
 Min.   :      1   Min.   :14.35   Min.   :0.0000   Min.   :1.000  
 1st Qu.: 375001   1st Qu.:36.64   1st Qu.:0.0000   1st Qu.:1.000  
 Median : 750000   Median :40.00   Median :0.0000   Median :1.000  
 Mean   : 750000   Mean   :40.00   Mean   :0.4007   Mean   :1.799  
 3rd Qu.:1125000   3rd Qu.:43.38   3rd Qu.:1.0000   3rd Qu.:3.000

    Location      Exposure             Salary             Claim

 Mean   :2.8   Mean   :1.5002358   Mean   : 41795.1   Mean   :0.002397  
 3rd Qu.:3.0   3rd Qu.:2.2502329   3rd Qu.: 53107.6   3rd Qu.:0.000000  
 Max.   :4.0   Max.   :2.9999990   Max.   :292813.0   Max.   :1.000000  </pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>[1] "Claim rate by occupation"
[1] "Occupation"
</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea ">
<pre>   
          0       1
  1 0.99738 0.00262
  2 0.99785 0.00215
  3 0.99781 0.00219</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Next, we can use density plots to check that ages are normally distributed and that salaries are a) gamma distributed and b) vary by occupation.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># view distribution of ages</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x<span class="o">=</span>Age<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> geom_density<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> theme_bw<span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It looks like age has been simulated as expected. The curve is bell shaped, the mean age is clearly 40 and most people are aged between 30 - 50, which is also in line with expectations given the variance we specified. To check that salary has been correctly simulated, repeat the <code>ggplot()</code> function but replace Age with Salary in the <code>aes()</code> (aesthetic) argument. We will also include an additional argument - <code>facet_wrap()</code> - to generate different density plots for each occupation group.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># view distribution of salary by occupation class</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> Salary<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
  geom_density<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
  facet_wrap<span class="p">(</span><span class="o">~</span>Occupation<span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span>
  theme_bw<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span>
ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Salary Dist. by Occupation Category"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>These look like gamma distributions and salary seems to be highest for occupation category 3 - which is correct!</p>
<p>In our assumptions table we state that salary should increase with age. We can check this using a scatter plot. Use <code>ggplot()</code> again but with <code>geom_point()</code> instead of density. Also, add <code>y = Salary</code> to the aesthetic.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># plot sample of age against salary</span>
<span class="c1"># (plot first 1000 rows for a better visual. 'pch = 21' controls the type of point)</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">[</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="m">1000</span><span class="p">,],</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> Age<span class="p">,</span> y <span class="o">=</span> Salary<span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> geom_point<span class="p">(</span>pch <span class="o">=</span> <span class="m">21</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> theme_bw<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Age/Salary Scatter"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Finally, view a bar chart showing counts of each location category. This time use <code>geom_bar()</code> and add <code>facet_wrap()</code> to view separate bar charts for each occupation class.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># distribution of locations by occupation</span>
ggplot<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">,</span> aes<span class="p">(</span>x <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">factor</span><span class="p">(</span>Location<span class="p">)))</span> <span class="o">+</span> geom_bar<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> theme_bw<span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
  facet_wrap<span class="p">(</span><span class="o">~</span>Occupation<span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
xlab<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Location"</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> 
ggtitle<span class="p">(</span><span class="s">"Location by Occupation Category"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Creating-new-Features">Creating new Features<a class="anchor-link" href="#Creating-new-Features">¶</a></h3><p>This last section will demonstrate how we could add some simple extra features to the dataset. These new features will be created using existing variables. Currently, age is exact and so we have lots of unique values. To reduce the number of distinct values I will create an 'Age_Last' variable. In addition, sometimes it is useful to transform numerical variables to categorical and so I will show you how to create a 'Salary_Band' feature from the numerical salary variable. This will group salary into a number of different categories which we will treat as nominal(you may also wish to treat these as ordinal factors).</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># create an 'Age_Last' variable from Age exact that we simulated earlier</span>
dt<span class="o">$</span>Age_Last <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">floor</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Age<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># we can also create a categorical variable from the raw numeric </span>
<span class="c1"># salary variable - e.g group into bins</span>
<span class="c1"># We will create groups using a helper function and custom defined breaks</span>
<span class="c1"># Bins can include, for example, those earning <25k, 25-35k, 35-45k, 45-75k,75k+</span>
<span class="c1"># (I've just arbitrarily picked these)</span>

quant_bin <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kr">function</span><span class="p">(</span>x<span class="p">,</span> breaks<span class="p">){</span>
  bin <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kp">as.numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kp">cut</span><span class="p">(</span>x<span class="p">,</span>
                       breaks <span class="o">=</span> breaks<span class="p">,</span>
                       include.lowest <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">T</span><span class="p">,</span> right <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">T</span><span class="p">))</span>
  bin
<span class="p">}</span>

breaks <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kt">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">25000</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">35000</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">45000</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">75000</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kp">max</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Salary<span class="p">))</span>

dt<span class="o">$</span>Salary_Band <span class="o">=</span> quant_bin<span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="o">$</span>Salary<span class="p">,</span> breaks<span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Now, view the first few rows of the data again</span>
<span class="kp">head</span><span class="p">(</span>dt<span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Summary">Summary<a class="anchor-link" href="#Summary">¶</a></h2><p>In summary, you should now be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Generate a table of assumptions</li>
<li>Simulate a large dataset using the assumptions table</li>
<li>Check summary statistics and visualise the data</li>
<li>Create some simple new features</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>

        "        preview: 'TeX'," +
        "    }, " +
        "    'HTML-CSS': { " +
        " linebreaks: { automatic: true, width: '95% container' }, " +
        "        styles: { '.MathJax_Display, .MathJax .mo, .MathJax .mi, .MathJax .mn': {color: 'black ! important'} }" +
        "    } " +
        "}); ";
    (document.body || document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0]).appendChild(mathjaxscript);
}
</script>
